questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of vaginal discharge and itching for 1 week. Upon examination, a profuse, thin, frothy yellow-green discharge and a strawberry cervix are noted. Which of the following statements regarding the causative organism is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Flagellated trophozoite is the infective form.

options.label: B
options.text: It has a characteristic twitching motility.

options.label: C
options.text: It has one anterior and 4 posterior flagella.

questions.correct_answer: C. It has one anterior and 4 posterior flagella.
questions.explanation:
Trophozoite

Feature

Trichomonas vaginalis

Giardia lamblia

Shape

Pear-shaped or ovoid

Heart-shaped or pyriform (tennis racket-shaped)

Size

10-30 µm in length, 5-10 µm in breadth

15 µm long, 9 µm wide, 4 µm thick

Flagella

Five flagella- Four anterior flagella and one along the undulating membrane

Four pairs of flagella arising from the blepharoplast

Axostyle

Prominent, runs the full length and projects posteriorly like a tail

One axostyle running along the midline

Cytoplasm

Contains prominent siderophilic granules along the axostyle and costa

It has two parabasal bodies

Movement

Rapid, jerky, or twitching motion

Slow oscillation resembling a "falling leaf" movement

Other Structures

Undulating membrane which reaches up to the middle of the body

Concave sucking disk on the ventral side for attachment to mucosa

Images

questions.text: A 42-year-old man from a rural area in Africa presents to the clinic with a two-week history of fever, headaches, and general malaise. He reports experiencing night sweats and often feels excessively tired during the day. On examination, there is notable posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings?
questions.explanation:
West African Trypanosomiasis

East African Trypanosomiasis

Parasite

Trypanosoma gambiense

Trypanosoma rhodesiense

Vectors-Tsetse fly

Glossina palpalis

Glossina morsitans

Primary reservoirs

Man-to-man transmission

Wild game animals

Illness

Chronic
  • Acute & rapidly progressive
  • Febrile paroxysms are more frequent
  • Myocarditis is more common & death may occur due to congestive heart failure

Duration of illness

Months to years

Less than 9 months

Lymphadenopathy (& Winterbottom's sign)

Prominent

Minimal

CNS involvement

Late

Early

Parasitemia

Low

High

Investigations
  • Microscopy- Trypomastigote in blood
  • Rodent inoculation- Not useful
  • Microscopy- Trypomastigote in blood
  • Rodent inoculation-Diagnostic

Treatment
  • Pentamidine
  • Eflornithine
  • Melarsoprol
  • Suramin
  • Melarsoprol

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the marked structure in the image below?

options.label: B
options.text: Present in organisms that live in the intestines

options.label: D
options.text: Contains nonnuclear DNA found in addition to the nucleus

questions.correct_answer: D. Contains nonnuclear DNA found in addition to the nucleus
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Kinetoplastida

Flagellates without Kinetoplast

Possess a kinetoplast

Yes

No

Flagella

Single flagellum

Multiple flagella

Examples
  • Trypanosomes
  • Leishmania
  • Giardia (Option C ruled out)
  • Trichomonas

Transmission

Transmitted by blood-sucking insects.

Causes systemic or local infections.

Live in the intestine. (Option B ruled out)

Called intestinal flagellates.

questions.text: Match the following 1. Leishman Donovan bodies a) 2. Dohle bodies b) 3. Henderson Petersen bodies c) 4. Cowdry Type A bodies d)
questions.explanation:
Histopathological Bodies in Microbiology

Leishman Donovan (LD) bodies

  • Found in untreated leishmaniasis.
  • They are light blue, ellipsoid structures measuring 2-4 μm in length.
  • LD bodies have an eccentric nucleus and a smaller kinetosome at the opposite pole.
  • These bodies are located within large macrophages (also known as Wright's cells).

Dohle bodies

  • Light blue-grey, oval, basophilic staining inclusions were found in the cytoplasm of neutrophils in the peripheral smear.
  • Seen in bacterial infections like tuberculosis, diphtheria, and typhoid,
  • Indicate defective neutrophil production and maturation.

Hendersen Petersen bodies

  • Molluscum contagiosum, caused by a poxvirus, is characterised by the presence of large, ellipsoid intracytoplasmic inclusions in the stratum spinosum and corneum of infected skin known as Henderson-Peterson bodies.
  • They are made up of nuclear and cytoplasmic protein aggregates and mark the site of viral replication.

Councilman Bodies

  • Acidophilic inclusion bodies are found in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes in viral infections like hepatitis and yellow fever.
  • These bodies result from hepatocyte apoptosis and are associated with ballooning degeneration of liver cells.

Cowdry Type A bodies

  • Cowdry bodies are eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions made of nucleic acid and protein, seen in infections like herpes, yellow fever, polio, and adenovirus.
  • Type A (found in herpes and yellow fever) appears as droplet-like masses with clear halos and chromatin margination around the nucleus.
  • Type B (associated with polio and adenovirus) lacks nuclear changes.

Negri bodies

  • Negri bodies are eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in neurons, primarily in rabies infection.
  • They represent sites of viral replication and are considered a hallmark of rabies in histopathological examination.

Torres bodies

The intranuclear inclusion body seen in liver cells infected with the yellow fever virus is composed of host proteins.

questions.text: Match the following 1. Darting motility a) Listeria monocytogenes 2. Swarming motility b) Trichomonas vaginalis 3. Tumbling motility c) Proteus 4. Jerky motility d) Vibrio

questions.explanation:
Organs of Locomotion in Protozoans

Amoebae

  • Entamoeba histolytica
  • Naegleria fowleri
  • Acanthamoeba

Pseudopodia

Flagellates

  • Trypanosoma
  • Leishmania
  • Giardia
  • Trichomonas

Flagella

Apicomplexa (Sporozoans)

  • Cryptosporidium
  • Isospora
  • Sarcocystis
  • Toxoplasma
  • Plasmodium
  • Babesia

Non-motile

Ciliophora

  • Balantidium coli

Cilia

questions.text: A 28-year-old male returns to his rural village after spending time in a forested area known for sandfly infestations. He presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his forearm that has gradually increased in size over the past month, as shown in the image below. The ulcer has raised, indurated borders and a necrotic base. The patient has no fever or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Type of

Leishmaniasis

Causative Organism

Clinical Features

Treatment

Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL)

L. tropica (Old World)
  • Painless ulcers with raised borders and necrotic base (often called "kala-azar ulcers").
  • Three patterns: Urban (dry, painless ulcers), Rural (moist ulcers), Diffuse (non-ulcerative)
  • Antimony (same as VL) or pentamidine for antimony-resistant cases.
  • Topical treatment: Charcoal in sulfuric acid paste or liquid nitrogen

Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis

L. braziliensis

Follows cutaneous leishmaniasis, involves nose, mouth, larynx (espundia), causing nodules, nasal septum perforation

Systemic treatment: Antimony; mucosal involvement may require additional therapies

Leishmaniasis Recidivans

L. species (varies by region)

Chronic lesions with alternating periods of activity and healing, resembling lupus or tuberculoid leprosy

Local heat application; chemotherapy not very effective; Leishmanin test strongly positive

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, previously treated for visceral leishmaniasis six months ago, now presents with multiple erythematous, hypopigmented, slightly scaly papules and plaques on her face, neck, and arms. The lesions are painless, gradually increasing in number, and there are no associated systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a 2-week history of fever, abdominal distension, fatigue, and significant weight loss. A rapid diagnostic test using the rK39 dipstick comes back positive. What is the recommended first-line drug for treating this patient’s condition?

A 20-year-old female from Africa presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pallor, and generalised lymphadenopathy. Given her clinical features, there is a high suspicion of kala-azar. Which laboratory tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? rk39 serological test Bone marrow aspirate Splenic aspirate Liver biopsy
questions.explanation:
Microscopy

Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL

 

Materials collected:

Peripheral blood smear: Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

 

Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows)

 

Bone marrow aspirate: Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Bone marrow samples can also be obtained by puncturing the Iliac crest.

 

Bone marrow aspirate showed Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies) in macrophages characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Fig. A and B).

Splenic aspirate (most sensitive): Splenic aspirates are richer in parasites and, therefore, are more valuable for diagnosis. Splenic aspiration is contraindicated in patients with prolonged prothrombin time or if platelet count is less than 40,000/mm³

Lymph node aspirate: It is not useful in the diagnosis of Indian kala-azar

Culture

Media: NNN (Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle).

Serodiagnosis
  1. Detection of antigen: ELISA and PCR
  2. Detection of antibody:
    • rk39 test: A specific rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) method for antibodies using a recombinant leishmanial antigen rk 39. The sensitivity of the test is 98% and specificity is 90%.
    • Complement fixation test
    • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT)
    • Counter immunoelectrophoresis (CIEP)
    • ELISA and DOT-ELISA
    • Direct agglutination test (DAT)

Non-specific serum tests
  1. Napier aldehyde test
  2. Chopra's antimony test

Skin test

  • Leishmanin skin test- Montenegro test: Delayed hypersensitivity test.
  • Positive result is indicated by induration and erythema of 5 mm or more after 48-72 hours.
  • Positive result indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasites. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after cure from the disease.

Image obtained after 48 hours after injection

Complete blood count
  • It shows normocytic normochromic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Leukocyte count reveals leukopenia.
  • The ratio of leukocyte to erythrocyte is greatly altered and may be about 1:200 to 1:100 (normal 1:750).
  • The serum shows hypergammaglobulinemia and a reversal of the albumin: globulin (A: G) ratio.
  • Liver function tests show mild elevations of liver enzymes.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male with a three-month history of fever, weight loss, fatigue, night sweats, and abdominal distention, along with splenomegaly, anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia, recently returned from rural India, where he was exposed to the vector given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the infective form of Leishmania donovani ?
Which of the following statements accurately describes the forms of Trypanosoma brucei that can be found in the blood of an infected individual?

options.label: A
options.text: The trypomastigote form is the only stage present in the blood.

options.label: B
options.text: The epimastigote form is commonly found in human blood during acute infection.

options.label: C
options.text: The procyclic form is typically present in the bloodstream of infected humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Both the trypomastigote and epimastigote forms can be found in human blood.

questions.correct_answer: A. The trypomastigote form is the only stage present in the blood.

West African Trypanosomiasis

East African Trypanosomiasis

Parasite

Man-to-man transmission

Wild game animals

Illness

Chronic
  • Acute & rapidly progressive
  • Febrile paroxysms are more frequent
  • Myocarditis is more common & death may occur due to congestive heart failure

Duration of illness

Months to years

Less than 9 months

Lymphadenopathy (Winterbottom's sign)

Prominent

Minimal

CNS involvement

Late

Early

Parasitemia

Low

High

  • Microscopy- Trypomastigote in blood
  • Rodent inoculation- Not useful
  • Microscopy- Trypomastigote in blood
  • Rodent inoculation-Diagnostic

Treatment
  • Pentamidine
  • Eflornithine
  • Melarsoprol
  • Suramin
  • Melarsoprol

Characteristic

Trypanosoma brucei

Trypanosoma cruzi

Leishmania

Classification

Flagellate protozoan

Flagellate protozoan

Flagellate protozoan

Subtypes

T.b. gambiense, T.b. rhodesiense

-

L. donovani, L. tropica, L. braziliensis

Disease Caused

African sleeping sickness (Trypanosomiasis)

Chagas disease

L. donovani: Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar)

L. tropica: Cutaneous

L. braziliensis: Mucocutaneous

Vector

Tsetse fly (Glossina)

Triatomine bug (“Kissing bug”)

Sandfly (Phlebotomus)

Infective Form

Trypomastigote

Trypomastigote

Promastigote

Chronicity / Progression

Gambiense: Slow progression

Rhodesiense: Rapid progression

Acute (mild) to Chronic (severe, e.g., cardiomyopathy, megaesophagus)

Progresses to chronic (Visceral: fatal if untreated)

Treatment

Suramin (early), Melarsoprol (late), Pentamidine and Eflornithine (alternative)

Nifurtimox, Benznidazole

Amphotericin B, Miltefosine, Sodium Stibogluconate

questions.text: Which organism does the following life cycle correspond to?

A 35-year-old woman with a travel history to South America presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, mild chest pain, and palpitations. She reports a history of fever, malaise, and swelling around her right eye 11 months ago, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, her heart rate is irregular, and she has mild cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. Which treatment options are most appropriate for her at this stage?
Which of the following culture media is used to diagnose T. cruzi?
questions.correct_answer: C. Yager’s LIT Medium (Liver Infusion Tryptose)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with persistent fatigue, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. He grew up in rural northern Argentina, where a childhood bug bite caused left eye swelling. Examination reveals leg swelling, an S3 gallop, and fatigue. IgG antibodies to Trypanosoma cruzi are detected by ELISA. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition? Cardiac manifestations are seen in 30% with chronic form of disease. Benznidazole is considered a drug of choice for the chronic form of disease. Chronic form of disease has cardiac and gastrointestinal involvement. Peripheral blood microscopy can be used to diagnose chronic disease. The acute form of disease presents with a generalised rash.
Which organism does this life cycle belong to?
questions.explanation:
• In the Reduvid bug: Epimastigote and trypomastigote are seen.
  • In adults: Amastigote and trypomastigote are seen.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice to treat Colpitis macularis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis?

A 32-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with vaginal discharge and itching for 1 week. Examination findings are provided below. Which of the following culture media cannot be used to identify the causative organism in this case?

A 30-year-old HIV-positive male patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhoea. The histopathology of the duodenum shows trophozoites in the duodenal wall, as shown in the picture below. Which of the following features is not seen in this condition?
A 28-year-old male patient is undergoing the test in the image below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: The Entero Test is used to diagnose giardiasis by obtaining duodenal specimens.

options.label: B
options.text: The String Test is used to diagnose amoebiasis by detecting trophozoites in the stool.

options.label: C
options.text: The Entero Test involves swallowing a coiled thread to diagnose echinococcosis by examining the liver.

options.label: D
options.text: The String Test is still widely used today due to its low cost and high diagnostic accuracy.

questions.correct_answer: A. The Entero Test is used to diagnose giardiasis by obtaining duodenal specimens.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and dehydration. A string test reveals a Giardia lamblia infection. After being treated with metronidazole, the patient does not fully respond, raising concerns about resistance. What would be the most appropriate next-line treatment?
